Opening of Parliament

Ottawa, Feb. 23.

Long before 10 o'clock to-day the hall began to fill up with people anxious to get a glimpse of the new Government. The doors opened the gallery was crowded and the floor of the Chamber was filled with members of the House, senators, judges and cabinet ministers.

Shortly after 10 o'clock His Excellency arrived and was greeted by a guard of honour from the Governor General's Body Guard, when the following detailed speech was delivered:

Government of the Legislative Assembly.

The negotiations between His Majesty's Government and those of the United States and Great Britain have been known as the fisheries question but I am pleased to inform you, resulted in a treaty which will I venture to hope be considered by both nations honorable and satisfactory to both nations.

Experience having shown that amend measures would not affect the provisions of the Act respecting elections, members of the House of Commons more effectually and more convenient in their operation, I have thought it desirable to make a measure for the amendment of that statute.

Legislation for the Northwest Territories renders essential an improvement in the system of government and legislation there. The present situation of the Dominion, and a bill for that purpose, will be laid before you.

A Bill will be submitted to you to make a complete adaptation of the modern laws of England applicable to Manitoba and the Northwest Territories in regard to matters of local administration. The Acts of the Parliament of Canada, but which have not yet been made the subject of Canadian legislation.

The extension and development of our railways have only rendered additional extraordinary safeguards for life and property, but they have also given occasion to questions in which the interests of rival companies are found to be in conflict. In order to prevent such adjustment a further legislation appears to be needed for these purposes. A measure will be submitted to you for the consolidation and improvement of the railway act.

Among other measures, bills will be presented to you relating to the judiciary. To the Civil Service Act, and to the audit of the Public Accounts.

The members have been returned to their chambers, the books containing the results of judgments of the courts in the recent elections and announced that a warrant will be issued for a second election in Russell. He announced the following vacancies—Dorchester, Charleswood, West Kildonan, Queen's N.R., Victoria and Carleton.

When the new members were introduced, Sir John made the usual formal motions, and then read the second reading of the Bill for the administration of oath of office and the appointment of standing committees.

The House was then adjourned until Friday.

Senator Hardisty arrived to-day.

TOWN COUNCIL.

An adjourned meeting of the Town Council was held last Friday evening at Mr. J. D. Hammond's, the president's residence, and the clerk was directed to advertise for a collector.

A by-law to provide for the organization and management of the fire brigade received three readings, and was ordered to be signed, sealed and numbered.

The draft petition or representation was presented, read and adopted.

There was also presented and read a draft petition for railway communication, but was deferred until a report was received.

The Council then adjourned.

The Council met again on Monday evening last, and adopted the draft petition brought in by the special committee to collect signatures.

The Council again met on Thursday evening, and the motion was passed approving the appointment of Mr. H. W. Macdonald as a delegate on behalf of the Town Council to go to Ottawa in connection with debate on the question raised by the Board of Trade and the Lorne Agricultural Society to present petitions relative to representation and railway communication.

Agricultural Society.

The annual meeting of the Carrot River Agricultural Society was held last Friday afternoon at the schoolhouse. In the absence of the president, the chair was filled by the late Mr. J. M. Clark.

The minutes of the last meeting having been read and approved, the election proceeded with, which resulted as follows:

President, Mr. John Sanderson.

Vice-president, Mr. C. S. Lowrie.

2nd Vice-president, Mr. Wm. Rossiter.

Secretary, Mr. James Tenney.

Two directors were appointed.

The Sec. Trust report to the meeting was very satisfactory, showing the society's balance sheet balance on hand of $156.47.

A vote of thanks has been tendered the retiring officers, the meeting adjourned to meet again at the request of the president.

Gentlemen are requested to attend the annual general meeting of the Carrot River Agricultural Society to be held at the schoolhouse at 8 o'clock p.m. on Tuesday next.

Capt. W. F. Meyers, of Kinistino, was in town this week.

TELEGRAPHIC.

Qu'Appelle, Feb. 23.—Great excitement prevails here over a case of high treason. Mr. Thomas Smith, a native collector, from Indian Head, left here on Monday night with about $800, but was robbed by Indians before he was able to reach his destination. They stopped him, bound, gagged and blindfolded him, then took his money and dragged him off toward Indian Head to near the reserve where he was killed. He managed to crawl to his own house, where he died. A large party of men left for there this morning. Nothing definite is known as yet.

London, Feb. 23.—A most interesting parade of Liberal and Parliamentary leaders was seen this season will end in London. The Government has sent the Lord Lieutenant of the province, the foreign policy of the Government and the Land Purchase Bill. The Lord Salisbury regime will be remembered as one to give the Liberals a victory in the Edinborough election.

While Mr. Richard Hardisty has been busy in the Northwest, and it is said officially that the Lord Governor-Douglas will not be able to attend the meeting.

At the annual meeting of the Liberal Conservative Association on Friday night Josephine Butler was presented by 129 votes to 124 for Sarah. Nine weeks ago the same ballot was given to Mr. Mulock, one of the scorers, who could not have given the majority. Mr. Butler expressed that the nine ballots were done up together and had been thrown in by one man. Mr. Butler said that he had said, before the election, that he would do his best to defeat him, asked Mr. Butler to explain why he voted which was refused. A scene of wild disorder ensued, lasting till midnight when order was restored.

Pant Duffield, late Viceroy of India, has accepted appointment as ambassador to Italy.

Various and contradictory reports are current regarding the fisheries treaty. Nothing definite is known as yet.

If the fisheries treaty is rejected, an important question will arise. It is reported that he will be appointed to settle the disputed question regarding the boundary line between British Columbia and Alaska.

In the earlier part of the evening Sir Donald Smith's trophy, Mark II, turned its rock, of the Granitic club, won.

Montreal, Feb. 23.—The secretary of the Board of Trade has written to the wheat board in Montreal, saying prices are too dear of Vancouver and Victoria, by Mr. McPhail, Secretary of Winnipeg Board of Trade.

The Reading, Pennsylvania, coal mine's strike was ended and the miners have returned to work.

Gladstone made a short speech in the House of Commons on Saturday night to assure the country that the government by old members to be one of the finest electoral efforts in the parliamentary career of the veteran statesman.

Michael Davitt, the Irish Fenian enthusiast in the big crowd, "the grand old man is good for fifty years yet," and Parnell replied, "he will live to witness the triumph of justice."
